jyJL3kE1G-naO9EDDKNzzQ.text: A great gathering place for the workers around Barbican/Farringdon area and I came on a Friday where the place was packed. Sat on the ground floor and drinks arrived pretty fast but food took at least 40 minutes to come out.Nevertheless, the waiters were friendly, the food was pretty good and I would come back again - but I would make sure that my boss knows I'm having a long lunch!

photos.caption: Photo of Smiths Of Smithfield - London, United Kingdom. Chicken curry with sweet potato shreds and bread
Photo of Smiths Of Smithfield - London, United Kingdom

YlRgyELHt1QG0qMdfgRczw.text: Very cool vibe, great music, trendy decor, cool staff. I had the tuna salad and it was delicious. Fresh and full of flavour. Would recommend.

photos.caption: Photo of Smiths Of Smithfield - London, United Kingdom. Tuna Salad

2Xn4zBV__r0Sk8_qZVnn3Q.text: Our dinner at the Top Floor at Smiths of Smithfield was very disappointing. I had been there a couple years back and it was fantastic so i had high hopes, unfortunately it was a completely different experience. The venue was fairly empty but it did fill up later in the evening. We had a round of cocktails which were decent I suppose. The starters were average, nothing special, not worth it, nothing stood out. The squid dish was not very good at all. Main course, 2 sirloins and one rump steak, I can only speak for my sirloin but for a place that looks to sell "rare breed beef, they are joking. My sirloin was super thin, so it was overpriced but more importantly than that, it was overcooked, had a fair amount of fat on one side - it looked like some  basic supermarket steak, really disappointing. Coffees were ok, the dessert was terrible - coconut dacquoise, the cake part was soaked in rum, there are alcoholic cakes which taste good but whoever made this one wanted to drown the cake, you literally took a bite and the alcohol gushed out, and all you tasted was rum, really disgusting. Food at restaurants can be bad, it happens but the icing on the cake was the service, I've never seen such a rude guy, he couldn't be bothered to say thank you or your welcome, nor smile. The best part was splitting the bill 4 way and before going to the second card he muttered under his breath loudly, "jesus Christ". As soon as that was done, it told him to take the service off, it was that insulting. Told the manager about this untrained moron of a waiter who apologized and offered to take the sour taste away with champagne but no thanks. We will never go back, I strongly advise you not to waste your time on this restaurant, its overpriced and not even good. There are so many better places for steak and the service, even McDonalds is better. Sadly we wasted our time but you don't need to.

Gn1VezFMgJaDtaw6alYBag.text: Nom nom nom! Came here for the bottomless brunch and my was I impressed!! The food was tasty and the waitress was on top form with making sure my glass remained to be topped up. Don't think my glass ever even reached half empty (let alone empty, empty) as the prosecco just kept flowing. The staff are really friendly and helpful and offered great service - I was really impressed with this place. The only reason Smiths isn't getting a 5* is the fact the seats aren't really comfy as they were low stools (the  seats for bigger groups were long benches so again didn't look very comfy). Also my mum wasn't impressed with the fact the poached egg had a solid yolk. If they had proper seats with backs and not just wooden blocks to sit on I would definitely award 5 stars. But saying that, I would definitely go back....the chocolate waffles were devine!!!

Photo of Smiths Of Smithfield - London, United Kingdom. Bottomless prosecco all morning and now they've left the bottle for us!!! Umm amazing

WKiBS6qLnXPIp_WuLWt7LQ.text: Here I am at one of the greatest meat markets in the World. I get plenty of great beef locally in the large cities nearby. They had a pork t-bone. I was looking for old school pork with some fat. I asked several times to make sure the pork would be cooked medium. I wanted to see pink. I was assured this would be the case.The pork comes out WAY over cooked. I asked about it, and the server said she'd ask the chef. The chef comes out. I tell the story while the others at the table agree I was pretty much over the top about wanting it pink. The Chef says that cooking it that way causes disease. It has to be well done. I'll skip the back and forth. In the end, he said he'd cook it that way, but take no responsibility for when I got sick. Even in the US, the USDA, the most conservative of groups, has dropped the temp for cooking pork from 160 to 145.So, in the end, decent pork. Nice wine. A great group of coworkers and clients to be with. That makes up for the cooking.

1jYqpVU7K5kQs1ouel9-Uw.text: I went to Smiths for the first time on Sunday, and I have to say I am very sorely unimpressed! I redeemed Timeout's £20 bottomless brunch offer with them, and everything from the reservation process to the food to the service was a nightmare!To reserve, you must send through your voucher number and security codes as detailed in the fine print. That's fine, however, I was clearly corresponding with several different staff members through their one inbox as I was asked to provide the same information on two occasions. If the staff had scrolled down in the thread this could have been easily avoided, and would have lead to having a much more professional service.The day before the reservation, I received a voicemail asking to confirm my reservation. I returned the call to confirm accordingly, but the woman on the line could not find my reservation! Absolutely ridiculous as she had called 15 minutes prior to confirm it! It ended up being that my reservation was not booked under my name which I had given in the original emails to reserve. See above regarding lack of communication and professionalism via email correspondence!Upon arrival at Smiths, we were greeted by a very sullen and unfriendly young woman who took a good minute or so to find our names on the reservation list. We were then seated at a tiny round table next to a pillar, which effectively made the space even smaller. Very disappointing for having had a reservation for over two weeks in advance! Upon arrival of our server, he noticed that we were having the bottomless brunch and before asking any questions (i.e.. how are you, can I get you any drinks) he demanded I show him my voucher number and security code. Not only was this beyond rude, I was not informed prior to coming that I would additionally be required to have a paper copy. The sullen hostess did not mention it upon seating us either. After finding the information requested on my phone, I had the humiliating and more frustrating than anything experience of having to confirm this with not just the server and hostess, but what appeared to be a more experienced server or manager as well. Standing at the front entrance with three staff members as they painstakingly confirmed each character of all four codes was ridiculous and maddening to the point where we almost felt we should leave entirely.Once they had confirmed the reservation, they did not apologise whatsoever for the inconvenience or thank me for providing the codes (again!) but simply said "it's fine". As the room we were in (Ground Floor Cafe) was exceptionally humid for a cloudy day, we asked to be seated outside. This was not a problem, other than the fact that the servers rarely ever made their rounds outside. After our first round of drinks (we chose mimosas) we sat outside for 10 minutes before I had to go inside to request more drinks. For a "bottomless" brunch, I found this to be terribly poor service.When our food finally arrived, it was truly disappointing. I wish I had taken a photo to show as proof! It arrived 30 minutes past ordering and was the stingiest sized portion (think child's meal) I've seen. I had ordered a avocado on toast with poached eggs, but got ONE piece of Tesco quality bread, a thin smear of avocado (just a bit more than what peanut butter on toast would be like) and two eggs so well done that they were NOT poached, but practically hard boiled! There was no oozing yolk in either of them, the yolks were hard all the way through BOTH! Honestly, I was so excited for this brunch and had such high expectations, but was very very disappointed in the whole experience. I'm not even a moaner and this is the first time I've felt I needed to post a review of this nature, as the service was just truly astonishingly horrible. There was not one redeeming factor either (i.e., good food bad/bad service or good service/bad food), as the entire trip we made out to Smiths was a waste of time and money.tripadvisor.co.uk/ShowUs…

Wb9MZ3z7im66dJzJni9QIA.text: I came here briefly after a networking event and it was pretty dead, though not the time most people go out perhaps. It was half nine on a Tuesday, so that may say something. They have an extensive gin menu if that's what you're into.It's quite rustic here; maybe too much so, as after half an hour off being there the ceiling gave way to a torrent of water. To be honest the high ceilings give it a spacious feel, though it just feels gloomy in there. The staff are fairly friendly but it's not somewhere I'd choose to hang out.

7qIf22Pmz9fyfCCTo7J5Wg.text: I would give this place 0 stars if I could. This was the single worst dining experience I have ever had in London. Service was terrible, food took forever to come out (45 min for breakfast?) and the food was horrendous. We purchased a timeout voucher for the bottomless drink brunch. Biggest waste of money we have ever spent and we will never visit this pathetic excuse for a restaurant again. When we arrived, they sent us to the third floor despite us explaining we had a timeout voucher and a reservation. When we got upstairs, we were told our reservation was for the first floor. Back down we go, waiting 10 minutes to be seated because they were so busy and had to figure out how to squeeze us in... When we made the reservation, we were very clear about it being for breakfast.When we were finally seated, the server told us we could have anything on the menu. I go to order pancakes, to be told it's not included in our voucher. We wait another 10 minutes for the manager to decide whether I would be allowed to order the pancakes. He took a further 5 minutes to 'debate with the head chef' as they were 'so busy, he doesn't have time to make anything not included on your voucher.' To be clear, the voucher does not disclude pancakes in its t&cs and its on the menu... So someone not using the voucher could order it? So would it still be such an inconvenience to the chef then? Finally I am allowed to order the pancakes and we receive our mimosas. We wait ages between refills. after 45 minutes the food finally arrives and it is horrendous. My pancakes are raw batter on the inside, the French toast tastes burnt and bitter and the waffles are burnt to a crisp. My partners poached eggs have a solid yoke, his bacon is rock solid and burnt, his hash browns are clearly out of a frozen pack and his hollandaise sauce tastes like butter.This is the worst place I have ever had breakfast. Stay away from this disaster of a restaurant.

pniG9byIntVubjsY7YK11w.text: Holy cow this place is awesome but expensive. To start, the cocktails are phenomenal. I got a gin order and he a rum-based one. Mine had the distinct taste of lime which cut into the gin nicely and my husband's raspberry tipple was incredibly sweet. He liked it and they are too easy to suck down!As for the meals, I ordered the Jerusalem Artichoke, Ricotta & Pine Nut Pithivier, Wild Mushroom Sauce (v) for 14 1/2 pounds and he got the 9oz South Devon Rib Eye, Chips, Mustard Mayo for 23 pounds My dish was PHENOMENAL.Holy cow. Holllllllllllly cow. Rich, creamy sauce with thick raviolis bursting with mushroom essence. I closed my eyes several times while eatng.My husband said his dish was OK- nothing spectacular.I also go the BOMBAY FIZZ-Devaux Champagne, Bombay Gin, Passion Fruit Puree, Gomme  for 12 pounds. Went down way too quickly again!For dessert, we split the Chocolate Delice, Pistachio Sauce, Chocolate Biscuit for 6 1/2 pounds. I again closed my eyes at the first and consecutive bites. One of the best chocolate desserts ever? Quite possibly. Also the Pecan Pie, Chantilly Cream, Rum Toffee Sauce for 7 pounds is possibly the best pecan pie I have tasted since the States.Service was hit or miss- I had to go up to the hostess table to get an initial server. At times a separate one checked in on us and other times, we were ignored.

FAF8nZrb_NLgtWuja_KkCg.text: This review is only for the top floor - maybe the bottom floor that is more casual and has craft beers, burgers, and more snack-like food is better, but I was disappointed with the top floor, fine-dining experience. It's not an inexpensive meal by any means, and for dinner and ~3 glasses of wine for the table, we each spent about $75-80 per person, which is not cheap. There's certainly better food in London at this price range.The place was super empty on a Monday evening, and there was maybe one or two other parties on the top floor while we were dining, so I'm not sure why the service was so painfully slow. It felt like an eternity for the food to come out.- Steak Tartare, Bloody Mary, Stout Pickled Onions, Smoked Egg Yolk  (£12.5) - Really delicious steak tartare, with the egg yolk on top that complemented it perfectly. I'd recommend this, and would get it again.- White Peach, Burrata, Black Olive, Cracked Pepper, Basil (£13) - This was one of the better burrata dishes that I ate during my week-long stay in London (having also eaten it at Spring and Padella). The burrata was fresh and paired nicely with the sweetness of the peach.- Rare Breed Sampler (£84) - 280gm/10oz Rump, 280gm/10oz Sirloin, 200gm/7oz Fillet  - The meat was good, as I would expect for a steakhouse. We split the sampler amongst 3 people, which was a good amount of food. You could do the sampler for up to 4 people also, and just add more sides. I wasn't sure which cut of meat was what while I was eating it, so I can't tell you what was the best of the 3, but the quality of the meat was good and it was cooked to our liking.- Lobster Mac 'n' Cheese (£7) - The noodles in the mac & cheese were small, and not your traditional elbow macaroni. Wasn't sure where the lobster was, since I didn't really see/taste too much of it, but the cheese they used was excellent and it was tasty. Just not sure they should tout it as lobster macaroni when it's hard to find/taste the lobster.- Creamed Spinach (£5) - You can't really go wrong with creamed spinach, it had a ton of cream in it, so it tasted good, but they almost put too much cream, as it was slightly on the watery side.All in all, it was a good meal, but minus stars for the service, and the price for what you got. I expected much better service if I was paying this much for a nice steak meal, and it took the server almost 30-45 min to bring us the check at the end of the meal. I could have probably left the restaurant and they wouldn't even have noticed. This is fine for a business meal if you're not paying out of your own pocket, but there are a lot of other high end restaurants for better prices out there. Not sure I would come back.

6Y5NYASCUQXLzByLnnunAQ.text: Bit of a breakfast regular here - the Breakfast No 2 can't be beaten!Good service.  Nice ambiance.  Great for meetings or general catch ups!

1605rRLPbuiSYOL2tOUNMw.text: Went for a business dinner with my team. Great food. We all had a variety of food, ribeye, scallops, chicken.... Servers were very friendly and always made sure our drinks were full, attentive! Would recommend. They have multiple floors. All with different menus which I found very cool!

photos.caption: Photo of Smiths Of Smithfield - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Smiths Of Smithfield - London, United Kingdom. Sweets menu

bg1Sta4dHbCAMRXeOljK8g.text: I would avoid the 2nd Floor dining room at this place. We went for a team lunch, table booked for 1pm for 11 people. The service was so slow it was basically none existent. Our food didn't come until after 2pm and though it was nicely presented they obviously struggled with our party size as it was clear most of the food had been sat on the side waiting.I ordered a rare steak and what arrived was cold and grey on the inside. My two other colleagues who ordered steak also complained of similar quality. The burgers were dry and lacking and salad or onions. The only positives were the chips and the pork belly dish.Would absolutely not recommend. We were so annoyed we asked for the service to be taken from the bill. Considering this place is easily £20 a head not including starters, desserts or a second drink I think they really need to sort out the quality.

7sbJElnvM1Z-vPibEVTmtQ.text: It's difficult to know how to approach a review for Smiths, as it's very much an acquired taste. We've been here many times, at different times of day and during busy and quiet times. Our overall impression is that, yes, it seems a couple of quid more than other places on average, but the food is also above average, albeit simple fare such as bacon butties and porridge.Its industrial appearance gives away its heritage (it was a building that stood empty for 40 years before being given a makeover), and it feels like you could be in New York. You could be mingling with families, bikers and city slickers when you visit, and the staff will make sure you get as good as anyone in terms of service quality, which is casual and friendly.You simply can't beat the porridge, which doesn't feel microwaved (I'm imagining a large cauldron that's lovingly prepared by an oat expert with a big stick). Toast is chunky, tea is tea-y and the bacon is generously piled between two blankets of what feels like homemade bread (or at least bought in from a decent bakery).So, because we always love coming here, and it lacks pretentious airs and graces, and does a fantastic porridge with banana and honey, it gets top marks. We'll forgive the tart orange juice.(Please note that this review is based on our downstairs experience. We haven't been upstairs yet.)

photos.caption: Photo of Smiths Of Smithfield - London, United Kingdom. The bar
Photo of Smiths Of Smithfield - London, United Kingdom. The kitchen
Photo of Smiths Of Smithfield - London, United Kingdom. Near the entrance

0N7i6HCH1W4kGlsVWz3RxA.text: Shall we have a dirty burger?Oooh, come on then, if you insist.Smith of Smithfields has the advantage of being right next to Smithfields (must be where they get their name from, eh?), which means that their meat is really good, and really fresh.I've tried a lot of dishes from there:- Their Caesar Salad - not enough for a main meal- Chicken Burger - was "okay" but not amazing.And well, we always end up going with the burger, because why not.Served in a brioche bun, the burger is what you would expect of a burger. It's nice, and it hits the spot.I swap my chips for a salad - for which they are really generous and the dressing is yum.Perfect spot for a quick team lunch - that's probably why we always end up going back!

VxzhBL1qYv2HTZZnhkPXwA.text: We went the as a group of 9, which can be hard to accommodate, but the staff at SOS was ready for us. I love their big square tables, the openness of the dining room and the food was pretty good as well. Downsides: you can't have their beer in the dining room, even though you can have it downstairs at the bar, you have a different bar menu upstairs. Which just doesn't make sense. We got it only after we asked our waitress to ask her manager. And another bad thing is that the men's bathroom is facing an office building across the street and people can see you if you're using the urinals, as there is nothing covering the windows.

vX-ULbNSPlrdI7CrH4DafA.text: Always fun at Smiths. Although sitting on benches is somewhat like school it works. Loud and brash from lunchtime onwards. Great fishfinger sandwiches served downstairs. A few celebs spotted heading to the upper floors!

zhgZ-Fahge58-6_toVU_Kg.text: Top floor restaurant: good service, but very pricey for what it is, and we particularly enjoyed the after dinner mice olympics.

hNLdpF_MXr_Xgd0bP9K0Sg.text: I was recently taken to lunch at Smiths to the top floor and absolutely loved it. Famous for it's meat dishes (it's a steak lovers paradise- I opted for a smoked eel starter followed by the daily special of steak and kidney pudding) the fish dishes are amazing too with all the fish being nothing less than perfectly cooked. The service is brilliant, all the wait staff are incredibly knowledgable about the menu and the wine. All the food is carefully sourced and excellent all round. The views are lovely over the city of london, this is an exceptional restaurant and you can tell that a lot of thought has gone into every element of it. Well done Mr Torode!

nPfEFgKGfNY6Bvna0a1YpA.text: Lots of choice for everybody with three floors, getting gradually smarter as you go up. Open, loft space with plenty of atmosphere. The menu provides plenty of choice and each time I have been there the food has been excellent quality, whether it be meat or fish. The service can be a little slow which is a problem if you are entertaining at lunchtime. Booking for the upstairs restaurants is essential.

0720cM2qXI4VnHSrwblmbg.text: A favourite for brunch at the weekend and having introduced it to many friends, a favourite meeting place. But even alone, I enjoy the friendliness of the place and the general atmosphere, vibrant but not overbearing. The space at the ground floor is open plan and people watching is absorbing. The bacon sandwiches are heaven but I also love the waffles with honey. If you are lucky, you might run into a pre wedding party, which is a lot of fun. The top levels have a gorgeous view of London. The only thing to improve is the speed of service, some times you have to wait for your order.

JCjnGKYn6nVQZ1fBhpvfwQ.text: Smith's of Smithfield is a large restaurant/bar near the famous meat-market at Smithfield. The restaurant is comprised of a number of different 'Floors'. For example the bottom floor is a bar and the top floor is a Gastro restaurant. As part of a business debrief I went to the top floor with workmates. I enjoyed the food quite a bit, but based on the premise that this is the 'best steak restaurant' in London I felt let down when I compared the quality and taste to one of the Gaucho's I have also been to. The menu is quite small and most of us had a steak of one type or another, no one was disapointed, but equally no one was raving about it. The price was also very high. Afterwards we retired downstairs to the large bar area. The cocktail and drinks menu was pretty tired and the very dim lighting couldn't hide the very rough decor. So overall, not quite sure what to make of this. Good food, but perhaps losing its way like the market nearby.

Oib8f9COdRd_CZAldmlUMw.text: A very good steak eating establishment with other dishes too. Top floor restaurant has some of the best views across London and a very nice outside balcony. Not at all stuffy with pleasant staff. Opposite is the meat market so an interesting are to wander around having eaten your fill. Not inexpensive but well worth the cost.

FX0wjZGPWnE86jPbr0HyCg.text: Smiths of Smithfields really is a place for everyone with different floors catering to different tastes. The bottom floor, always busy, is a lot more casual, complete with leather couches, and serves some great grub for breakfast. The floors become more formal (and so does their price) as you move up in the building. John Torrode, the owner, doesn't seem to have any problems mixing food from different regions and sometimes the menu reads like an international gathering. Fortunately each dish that I've had here always seems to be perfectly done. I have to give extra mention to their perfect pork belly dish, as I normally don't eat the skin yet I couldn't think about wasting any part of theirs.

gq0asSbSEFOU_2YvWXA1mg.text: Not for vegetarians... this is the real thing for meat lovers. The restaurant is part of the Smithfield meat market, which is itself worth a visit. The restaurant is in a beautiful old building with open brickwork and dark leather chairs. The food is simple but the ingredients are excellent (well the meat anyway). They serve traditional British fare - heavy on meat of course but you can also eat eels and other English delicacies. Prices are on the high side - possibly too high for what you get your plate. That, with sometimes distracted service, are the only downsides.

D2Yslcu0RJQNLmRd2tpe3w.text: Smith's of Smithfield is a lunch bar. There is also a gastronomic restaurant on the top floor of the building. I think there is also a wine room on the 1st floor. The only floor affordable is the ground floor ;-) though. Their lunch menu is quite good. Their sandwiches and salads are great, very different compared to what you've already tasted (they add their own ingredients and the result is nice). It's a bit more expensive but it's worth the money.

eFACnv0yCc8IxGw8K0vsig.text: Smiths is popular with large parties, and there is masses of space to cater for them, but it means that the restaurants can get very noisy in the evenings. The food is good, but not exceptional, and they might consider offering a wider range of cuts of meat. I'm never keen on places that put someone in the toilet to offer aftershaves and lollipops (rotten job and a bit hard for the customer to say 'no' to). Service is fine. Overall, good, but could be a lot better.

KwndW_aISIHBRI9qkzbOUg.text: Been a while since I've been here, but I really must get the all new Steak fiend badge, so here we are. I seem to remember it being incredibly busy, noisy, and the food being pretty good. Well, I can't remember that much to be honest because I fell asleep on the table. Again. Whoops.

oN2Nvj4WKDOXAwp4gqravw.text: Fish finger sandwich is good, as are the chips. Specials ALWAYS seem to have sold out. Food is good, but not brilliant, a little pricey.

s7kmLExkIWjzW2QZ2s5LtQ.text: Great for parties - though it's got high minimum spends and needs to be booked early. John Torode himself will come along, if you want to book him too.

photos.caption: Photo of Smiths Of Smithfield - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Smiths Of Smithfield - London, United Kingdom

KRCLBLw7xQNJGj6Z8Wbygw.text: I know their thing is meat, but I like to come here for drinks, as the ground floor opens up to casual drinks crowd at night and sometimes has a dj spinning some tunes off in the corner.  It's got a decent selection of drinks and lots of seating so whenever hopping around for pints and cocktails near Smithfield, this has got to be a stop.  The lunch crowd can be a bit much, so if you've only got a short lunch break, you might need to do some planning ahead.  Sadly my bank acct doesn't allow me to go to the upper floors but I've been admiring the menus from afar.

SKOM8Jyt19QyIYrSxGxz1Q.text: Bar/cafe on ground floor was excellent! Great atmosphere in the afternoon. Food was filling and good value. Cappuccino was excellent with lots of foam unlike a lot of London/Oz Cafes now serving latte art. Smoothie (Beetroot) was really good but on the expensive side.Overall a really good enjoyable experience. And a bonus was that John Torode was on on the next table to us!

UKvQC5NJ_SnJtTdrTX7Wew.text: A fantastic market in the centre of London. Not only fresh meat, but also 2 deli shops selling cheeses, trays of cakes & sweets, bulk pates, frozen food, salami, sauces & more. The best steak in London & all so fresh. At Christmas they sell a larger range of turkey, ham & other festive specialities. The parking is also free in December in the spiral carpark opposite, otherwise its only a few £'s. The only reason I havent given 5 stars, is I found it difficult to find free range chicken there. One shop sold whole, free range chickens from abroad, but surely there are British suppliers that arent prohibitively expensive? You'll find everything from poussins, Argentinian steak, suckling pig & more.

opxQ22c83432gDMVgsKPCw.text: I liked this place...stopped for a few beers last week! I liked that the tap larger was not just run of the mill. Couches were compfy and the music good. I suspect I will go back.

04sQy8TMfVODEZidlTKHwQ.text: Had breakfast here and was pretty impressed with quality and service. A good selection - I had poached eggs on toast and waffles with maple syrup, however full range of full English style breakfasts also available. A good start to the day.

7M3jX1BUSIiO5mhRvzHNtg.text: I went there twice, once for drinks downstairs. Great, spacey, and full party atmosphere. The other time was for diner for a birthday party. Nice food but too crowded/noisy to my taste. We were 15 and I could only hear my nearest neighbor. and while re food was nice, you can't really enjoy it IMO. So go for drinks and party, pass for diner.

rVb9O4NjScXQaxWQqHgmwg.text: It depends on which level you go to at Smiths of Smithfield. The lower levels are quite casual and I have visited them previously, this time I went to the fine dining restaurant on the top floor which serves a mean steak at a suitably high price (£28.50 since you are asking). See full review at gourmet-chick.blogspot.c…

WilAW7XzzXy4LodKctg0Bg.text: A splendid, lively bar and bistro on the ground floor, with posher fare upstairs. There's always a real buzz in this welcoming restaurant opposite Smithfield market. No surprise that John Torode's menu is heavy on the meat, but all tastes are catered for. If you have to wait for a table, there are huge comfy sofas where you can relax with a drink and take in the atmosphere. From the toilet windows, you can watch people passing by in tube trains, but they can't see you. I hope not anyway.

NmCH1H-Sjf5yEBsRIg7a4A.text: Smiths has something for everyone. Lovely place for brunch on the weekend or a bigger night out. The steaks are delicious at the restaurant on the 3rd floor and the views to St Pauls are lovely.

iwyBLOs4siNQuQ7xu8Bxjg.text: This is a review for the ground floor area. Went a few times over the years. Decor: nice-modern-factory like, music: too loud (if you come to chat with friends, not the right place) / toilet: normal, nothing special (in the past, you were expected to leave money for using it, not sure if it is still the case now) / drinks: good selection of beer and wine though a bit pricey / service: smiley staff / food: ouch! I ate there a few times but it was expensive for what I got, and never that good. The main reason why I am posting today is that my partner went there last week with colleagues for a full English, and after about an hour, all of them felt a bit sick in the stomach, and that lasted all afternoon. Not sure about the others, but my partner was then violently ill for 3 days after that and he still can't eat normally now. When he mentioned that to a different colleague yesterday, that colleague said that he heard of hygiene issues that SOS is facing. Well, that would explain! Never again until they sort it out...

tHs96mMyW4JWHPHgLk1IRw.text: Smiths of smithfields is a great bar any night of the week. Whether you are after a couple on Mon-Weds or joining the afterwork crowd on Thursday or Friday. Or even as a warm up venue before you hit the clubs around Farringdon. The many times I've been in it's been nice and busy and they're own brewed beers always hit the spot. Also there are another two levels above the bar on the ground floor that host their cocktail bar and restaurant. Apparently a great spot to go to over the summer as the views across the city are spectacular.
